<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of find_entry_by_username:
```c
static struct UserEntry *
find_entry_by_username (const char *const username)
{
  size_t i;

  for (i = 0; i < (sizeof(user_ids) / sizeof(user_ids[0])); ++i)
  {
    struct UserEntry *entry;

    entry = user_ids + i;
    if (0 == strcmp (username, entry->username))
      return entry;
  }
  return NULL;
}
```

explanation: I selected fragments that are directly relevant to verifying Rule 14.2 (the loop counter declaration and initialization, the three clauses of the for header, any objects used in the loop condition, the increment expression, uses of objects from the body that also appear in the condition, and calls inside the loop body). Other parts of the function do not affect the well-formedness of the for loop as defined by Rule 14.2 and therefore do not need further investigation for this rule: the function signature/static storage specifier, the block delimiters ({ }), the local declaration 'struct UserEntry *entry;' (its declaration alone does not change loop-counter semantics), the 'return entry;' and 'return NULL;' statements (they do not modify the loop counter or the loop-condition objects in a way relevant to Rule 14.2), and simple assignment/whitespace formatting. These items do not introduce additional loop counters, do not appear in the for-clause expressions, and do not call or modify objects in a way that would alter the for-loop clauses per Rule 14.2, so they are not flagged for investigation here.
